double libpg::RLAlg::evaluate ( Vector &  totalRewards,
int  steps 
) [virtual]

Just do an evaluation phase with the most probable action. This gives a different answer from doSteps without learning because doSteps is still following the stochastic policy.

Just do an evaluation phase with the most probable action. This gives a different answer from doSteps without learning because doSteps is still following the stochastic policy. If you are using your own controller, and you haven't implemented getMostProbAction, you will get the default behavious which is to just call getAction.

Parameters:
empty rewards vector to populate
number of steps to evaluate for

Acts a bit like learn, where evaluate is the equivalent of doSteps Does sets of stepsPerEpoch evaluations, but includes timing and printing of performance information.

virtual void libpg::RLAlg::setUseAutoBaseline ( bool  ubl  )  [virtual]

Automatically estimate the baseline over an epoch and subtract that baseline from any rewards in the next epoch. Do not use if your rewards are mostly 0 (results in less efficiency in gradient update), but generally a good idea otherwise.

Definition at line 104 of file RLAlg.hh.

double libpg::RLAlg::learn ( int  stepsPerEpoch,
int  maxTime = 0,
int  ms = 0,
double  maxVal = 0 
) [virtual]

Do optimisation until either time expires or steps runs out. We train in epochs of a fixed number of steps, reporting after each epoch. We get the initial reward by running for an epoch without learning. This initial epoch does not count towards step totals or final long-term average reward or time

Parameters:
steps per epoch
time limit (0 for no limit [default])
steps (0 for no limit [default])
max value (0 for no limit [default])
Returns:
final epoch reward

double libpg::RLAlg::learnCore ( int  stepsPerEpoch,
int &  totalSteps 
) [virtual]

By default this is very simple, call doSteps for stepsPerEpoch times, leaving online learning to doSteps. In other RLAlgs this might call doSteps to build up a batch estimate and then do a line search.

Reimplemented in libpg::GPomdp, and libpg::LineSearchAlg.

void libpg::RLAlg::checkStepSize ( double  curr,
double  best,
double  last 
) [virtual]

Do automatic scalar step size update. Will be redundant if using SMD. Very dumb: attempts to back off quickly if policy dies catastrophically, and slowly increase if we stop learning fast enough. Should help to go to a more deterministic policy. This is not a substitute for a good initial step size, but it will hopefully save you if things go bad half way through optimisation.

Parameters:
current average reward
best average reward
average reward **last time checkStepSize** was called.

Restore the best parameters recorded in file "savename". Should be used after optimisation, before using the policy.

bool libpg::RLAlg::testForHalt ( time_t  secs,
int  steps,
double  val 
) [virtual]

User can override halting conditions with this function.

Returns:
true if user should halt.
Check all the halting conditions. This is provided for convenience of users to override for their own halting conditions.
Parameters:
wall clock time how long the current learn() call has been running
steps the total learning steps in the current learn() call
val the current long term average reward (over last epoch)
Returns:
true if optimisation should halt

Vector libpg::RLAlg::baseline [protected]

Baseline for reward measure. The reward for each step will have the baseline subtracted from it. Idea is to reduce the variance in gradient estimates by turning the rewards into a zero mean process. Typical baseline is the long-term average reward, but that's not known. DEFAULT: 0.0 SEE-ALSO: useAutoBaseline();

Definition at line 22 of file RLAlg.hh.

Referenced by libpg::GOALPomdp::doSingleEpisode(), libpg::OLPomdp::doSteps(), libpg::GPomdp::doSteps(), libpg::GOALPomdp::doSteps(), learnCore(), libpg::LineSearchAlg::learnCore(), libpg::GPomdp::learnCore(), resetLearning(), and RLAlg().

bool libpg::RLAlg::useAutoBaseline [protected]

If true, baseLine will always be set to the long-term average reward from the last epoch DEFAULT: false

Definition at line 28 of file RLAlg.hh.

int libpg::RLAlg::epochsBetweenStepUpdates [protected]

Shall we automatically update the scalar step size using a naive algorithm.. Use with caution. Probably still requires a degree of fine tuning for a class of problems. Any SMD algorithm will ignore this.
